Award.AwardTitle: Fourth International IEEE Conference on Computational Advances in Bio and medical Sciences (ICCABS) - Travel Awards

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Broader Significance and Importance
This proposal is to support the travel of students and post-doctoral fellows (PDFs) to attend the 4th International Conference on Advances in Bio and medical Sciences (ICCABS). These students and PDFs will get to meet experts in Bioinformatics and listen to their research results. Not only the attending students and PDFs but also their friends will benefit since when the students and PDFs return to their schools they will communicate their experience with their friends. The conference proceedings will be of great use to students, researchers, and practitioners. Portions of the proceedings could be used in different courses as well.

Technical Description of the Project
Computational techniques are revolutionizing the way in which research is conducted in science and engineering. Unsurpassed advances have been made in various areas. This is particularly true in the domains of biology, medicine, and drug discovery. Given that these areas are of utmost importance to the society at large, it is imperative that every effort be made to enable research advances in them. It is not enough if advances are made in these areas in isolation. These communities have to work together to help each other and come up with the best possible diagnosis tools, treatment procedures, drugs for various diseases, etc. Even though a number of conferences exist today in the general area of bioinformatics, they focus on computational biology to a large extent. The proposed conference has the goal of bringing together scientists in all the three areas and hence serving as a platform for bridging the research efforts in these areas.

The intellectual merit of this project lies in its goal of bringing together scientists in various areas of bio and medical sciences and fostering collaborations among them.

1. Conference Summary

The Fourth ICCABS was held at the Miami Beach Resort and Spa, Miami Beach, FL, from June 2nd to June 4th, 2014.

 

The conference was a great success as reported by the attendees. Around 75 registrants attended the conference. All the talks were well attended and appreciated. The social events were also a big success!

 

Funds from NSF were used to support 15 graduate students and two post-doctoral fellows who represented 10 different universities (including a university in Canada).

This is particularly true in the domains of biology, medicine, and drug discovery. Given that these areas are of utmost importance to the society at large, it is imperative that every effort is made to enable research advances in them. It is not enough if advances are made in these areas in isolation. These communities have to work together to help each other and come up with the best possible diagnosis tools, treatment procedures, drugs for various diseases. Even though a number of conferences exist today in the general area of bioinformatics, they focus on computational biology to a large extent. The proposed conference has the goal of brining together scientists in all the three areas and hence serving as a platform for bridging the research efforts in these areas.

 

3. Conference Topics

The topics of interest to the conference spanned biology, medicine, and drug discovery. Some of the broader topics covered were: Biomedical image processing, Biomedical data and literature mining, Biological Big Data, Computational genetic epidemiology, Computational metabolomics, Computational proteomics, Databases and ontologies, Gene regulation, Genome analysis, Health Informatics, High-performance bio-computing, Immunoinformatics, Molecular evolution, Population genomics, Sequence analysis, Structural bioinformatics, Systems biology, Transcriptomics, etc.

 

4. Organizational Structure

The steering committee consisted of distinguished scientists: Srinivas Aluru (Iowa State University), Reda A. Ammar (University of Connecticut), Tao Jiang (UC Riverside), Vipin Kumar (University of Minnesota), Ming Li (University of Waterloo), Sanguthevar Rajasekaran (Chair, University of Connecticut), John Reif (Duke University), and Sartaj Sahni (University of Florida).

 

General Chairs of the conference were Sitharama Iyengar (Florida International University), Sanguthevar Rajasekaran (University of Connecticut), and Sartaj Sahni (University of Florida). Program Chairs were Jake Y. Chen (Purdue University Indianapolis) and Vasant Honavar (Pennsylvania State University). Yury Khudyakov (CDC/CCID/NCHHSTP), Ion Mandoiu (University of Connecticut), and Alex Zelikovsky (Georgia State University) served as Workshop Chairs. Publicity Chair was Bob Weiner (University of Connecticut). Reda A. Ammar (University of Connecticut), Mukul Bansal (University of Connecticut), and Yufeng Wu (University of Connecticut) were Finance Chairs. Local Arrangements were handled by Shu-Ching Chen (Florida International University).

 

The Program Committee had around 50 members.
